Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.time_to_resolution: Less than 12 months—question is about 2025 NCES data, likely published Spring/Summer 2026.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS Enrollment Data Monitoring), I have deep familiarity with how U.S. postsecondary data are collected and reported in the NCES Digest of Education Statistics, understand the drivers of enrollment shifts (domestic/international, demographic, policy), and can interpret current data signals in light of longstanding base rates and leading indicators.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.status_quo: The four-year college enrollment rate of 18-24-year-olds was 29.9% in 2015. As of recent years, the trend has been slowly downward, but has not fallen sharply. The 2024 NCES data for this age/rate was likely close to or just below 28-29%, per typical annual drift.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sharp drop in international student enrollment due to 2025 visa crisis
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases the probability, as international students form a nontrivial proportion of 4-year enrollments and this disruption was severe and poorly timed to be offset.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Continuing secular decline in domestic 18-24 population and college-going rates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately decreases the probability, amplifying the structural 'demographic cliff' and shifts in attitudes toward college worth.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Colleges aggressively lowering barriers to admission
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases the probability by helping capture more marginal domestic students, partially offsetting declining supply of applicants.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Ongoing disillusionment with higher ed value proposition (debt, ROI concerns)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately decreases the probability, as data and media highlight skepticism, pressuring further enrollment contraction.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent policy shocks (federal funding cuts, Trump administration visa rules, early decision litigation)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases the probability by creating uncertainty and barriers at the institutional and student level.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rates and historical inertia in enrollment data
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases the probability—these rates typically move slowly year-to-year, limiting downside risk of a sudden collapse below 26.6% barring a major exogenous shock.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.no_scenario: 2025 NCES data reports a national 18-24-year-old four-year college enrollment rate at or below 26.6%, due to compounded effects of the international student collapse (17% new international drop), heightened visa denials, shrinking domestic cohorts, and acceleration of skepticism about college value, with policy shocks exacerbating a multi-year decline. Even aggressive last-minute admissions efforts are not enough to reverse these headwinds, and the data series confirms Knoche's criterion was met: >10% drop since 2015.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.yes_scenario: Despite a turbulent year, colleges successfully recruit enough marginal domestic students, late international arrivals, transfers, or 'stopouts' returning to keep the 18-24 four-year enrollment rate above 26.6%. The impact of international student loss, while visible, is offset by increased persistence/retention in upper-class cohorts, and the rate drops but stays above the critical 26.6% threshold, allowing Caplan to narrowly win.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.final_reasoning: Base rates suggest a slow drift, not an abrupt cliff, but 2025 saw converging shocks: the international student visa processing crisis resulted in a 17% drop in new overseas enrollments, especially affecting the 18-24 age group in four-years (note: most international students are in graduate programs, but the undergrad four-year share is still material and disproportionately valuable for keeping above the threshold). Domestic headcount is constrained by the demographic cliff (fewer HS grads), and public skepticism remains acute. Recovery in international numbers for late arrivals or OPT/carryover is unlikely to fully offset the 2025 disruption, as data show numbers down in both India and China. Numerous schools reported financial strain and open seats. While some resilience is provided by policy flexibility (no test, fee waivers, direct admit), and by the slow year-on-year nature of reporting, the combined magnitude of these negative shocks is high. My best estimate is that the enrollment rate in 2025 will slide to or just below the 26.6% cutoff—close, but more likely under than over, as this represents a compound exogenous shock on top of structural decline. Thus, I put the probability of Caplan winning (rate >26.6%) at 40%, i.e., below even odds, but not extremely low, because of base rate inertia and possible reporting/preliminary data discrepancies.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.time_to_resolution: Approximately 12 months (question resolves when final 2025 NCES data is released, likely late 2026, but the enrollment rate is determined by 2025 data).
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.perspective_relevance: As an expert in higher education policy analysis, especially with a focus on postsecondary access policy, I am attuned to enrollment trends and their drivers—including domestic demographic shifts, immigration policy, public perceptions of higher education value, admissions practices, and institutional finances. My perspective is particularly relevant right now given the interplay between U.S. postsecondary access (for domestic and international students) and current policy disruptions, notably the severe 2025 international student visa crisis.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.status_quo: The status quo (if nothing significant changed from the past several years) would be a slow, steady decline in U.S. four-year college enrollment among 18-24 year-olds. However, the base rate for recent years has hovered slightly above the threshold: 29.9% (2015), estimated ~28.0–28.5% (2021–2024), so a continued gentle decline might put 2025 in the 27.0–28.0% range absent major disruption.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The declining number of U.S. high school graduates (projected for this decade) and an 8.4% drop in total college enrollment 2010–2024 means the base pool remains stagnant or shrinking.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Massive Drop in International Student Enrollment due to 2025 Visa Breakdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The 17% drop in *new* international college enrollment—triggered by a catastrophic visa processing failure during the most important admissions window—represents an unprecedented shock, concentrated at four-year institutions (especially selective publics and privates). Many of these students never arrived, shifted to other countries, or deferred.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Simultaneous Declines in Chinese and Indian Students
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Chinese enrollment has been falling for years; now India—which surpassed China as the top sender—is down nearly 45% in the summer/fall of 2025 alone. Together, these groups make up the majority of international undergraduates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional Response: Aggressive Domestic Recruitment/Admission Policy Easing
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Proactive campaigns—waiving application fees, auto-admits, deadline extensions, and direct admit—boost domestic enrollment margins, and give students more access, but cannot fully compensate for loss of international students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perception of College Value and Financial Barriers
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. With only 22% of Americans believing a degree is worth the cost if financed via loans, and increased concern about return on investment, more students may opt out, especially in a softer labor market or amid family financial stress.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Potential Countervailing OPT (Optional Practical Training) Effect
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Minimally increases probability. While new international student entry plunges, some international enrollment figures may be buffered by OPT—students who finish undergrad and stay on a university-sponsored work visa—though the bet resolution is focused on 'enrollment' of 18-24s, not total student count.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.no_scenario: In this scenario, cumulative shocks win out: the historic drop in international undergraduate enrollment from visa failures and policy headwinds—combined with continued demographic decline of U.S. high school graduates and a tepid domestic applicant pool—pushes 2025's fraction of 18-24 year-olds enrolled in four-year colleges to 26.6% or lower. Institutions' mitigation measures (aggressive recruitment, easing admissions) partially dull the effect, but not enough to offset international shrinkage, and the number dips just past Caplan's loss threshold.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.yes_scenario: In the alternative, U.S. colleges overcompensate for international losses by expanding domestic intake at the margin (especially at less-selective four-years), e.g., with blanket auto-admit policies, record numbers of fee waivers, and extended deadlines. Additionally, some international students who initially deferred ultimately enroll later in fall or the next spring (counting for 2025). Stable or recovering OPT/fifth-year international students help stabilize headcounts. The fraction of 18-24 year-olds enrolled in four-year institutions stays slightly above 26.6%—Caplan wins, but perhaps only by a few tenths of a percentage point.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.final_reasoning: Historically, U.S. four-year college enrollment rates among 18–24 year-olds have been slowly declining since about 2010, but not precipitously—typically dropping by 0.2–0.5 percentage points annually. However, the 2025 visa system meltdown is a rare, negative one-off shock to the pipeline of new international undergraduates, compounded by an ongoing demographic contraction of the prime college-age U.S. cohort. Institutional countermeasures—policy relaxations and outreach—can blunt, but not fully neutralize, this shock. While some backfill from domestic students is likely (via relaxed admissions and late offers), the base rate for 2024 was likely only 27.2–27.8%, with 2025 poised for a steeper drop due to this year's unique events. Historical precedent (COVID shock in 2020-21) shows similar drops (up to 2 percentage points in a year under exceptional circumstances) are possible. Given the magnitude of the international hit—especially in undergrad entry, compounded by lower U.S. yields and negative attitudes toward higher-ed value—the probability that enrollment dips to or just below 26.6% in 2025 is now quite high, though not absolutely certain. Therefore, I judge that Caplan is unfortunately likely to *lose* his bet; the probability the rate is ABOVE 26.6% is about 30%.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.time_to_resolution: Data for 2025 college enrollment rates will be released in mid-2026; question resolves soon after, so ~7 to 8 months remain.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Demographic Analysis using the Cohort Component Method, my unique perspective is to forecast the enrollment rate by integrating the latest demographic data (size of the 18–24 cohort), applying base rates for enrollment trends, and factoring in components affecting each subgroup (natives/internationals, by gender, income, etc.). This method allows a granular analysis of drivers and obstacles to enrollment, including domestic trends and the outsized influence of international students.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.status_quo: The college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in four-year institutions has trended downward, but declines have been relatively gradual. In 2015, it was 29.9%. Last publicly available figure (2023 Digest, Table 302.60, for year 2022) was approximately 27.1%. If the 2025 rate is above 26.6%, Caplan wins.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The 'demographic cliff' driven by shrinking high school graduate cohorts (already evident in the 2020s) means fewer potential college entrants, creating downward pressure on the enrollment RATE unless college-going behavior changes counteract this.

Slightly increases probability. While domestic demand has softened due to skepticism about ROI, extended application windows, direct admissions, and aggressive recruiting suggest colleges are working hard to prop up numbers, preventing a dramatic collapse.

Strongly decreases probability. The cited articles report a catastrophic 17% drop in new international student enrollment (key group for four-year colleges), especially among Indians and Chinese. This follows reported visa processing failures, negative perceptions, and worsened geopolitics. Overall foreign enrollments are only slightly down due to graduate retention, but for 18-24-year-old undergrads, this drop will bite especially hard.

Decreases probability. Suspension of student visa processing and high denial rates in 2025 coincide with peak application windows, making the effect acute. Policy reversals have come too late to rescue the Fall 2025 cohort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: College Response (Recruiting Rate, Lowered Standards, Scholarships)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Partially offsets decreases. As competition for students intensifies, colleges are using all means to increase yield—waiving fees, lowering academic requirements, auto-admitting on benchmarks, etc. This helps, but cannot fully compensate for international declines and the demographic cliff.

Decreases probability. The drop in perceived ROI (only 22% view college as worth loans) will continue to drag on first-time enrollments, although sharp year-to-year movements are rare except in crises.

Moderate-to-strong decrease. Recent base rate: from 29.9% to ~27.1% over 7 years (2015-2022)—about 0.4 percentage points drop per year. Extrapolating linearly to 2025 projects 25.9%, but pre-2025 did not have a collapse in international freshmen. If the 2025 drop is steeper, there is heightened risk.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.no_scenario: Colleges partially compensate for the loss of international students with increased domestic recruitment and aggressive yield strategies. Domestic 18-24 enrollment stabilizes due to easier admission, waived fees, and test-optional policies. The international cohort begins to recover due to late visa improvements and pent-up demand. The net result is a four-year rate just over 26.6% (e.g., 26.9%).
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.yes_scenario: Visa system failures, political hostility, and an accelerating demographic cliff cause a steeper-than-usual drop in both domestic and international enrollments. International freshman numbers—key to sustaining four-year enrollment—fall sharply and are not offset by other means. The cumulative effect is a rate below 26.6%, e.g., 25.7%.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.final_reasoning: Cohort component analysis indicates that the 18–24 US cohort is declining modestly, but the main story for 2025 is the collapse in new international student enrollment (~17% drop) due to visa dysfunction and an unwelcoming policy environment. Recent historical base rates show a decline of ~0.4 percentage points/year, which on its own would put the 2025 rate dangerously close to the 26.6% threshold. However, the drop in international undergrads—especially from India and China, who together are a disproportionate share of four-year enrollees—suggests a sharper short-term drop than linear projection. Aggressive college attempts to shore up numbers will give some offset, but historically, sharply negative exogenous shocks (visa freezes, geopolitical shifts) tend to produce clear and rapid effects on enrollment, not just applicant pools. In short: If the international intake hit is as severe as reported, the 2025 rate is likely to dip below the threshold even if domestic factors are flat. However, a plausible margin of error exists—post-October visa processing may help a little. I judge there's about a 70% chance Caplan does NOT win the bet (i.e., the rate falls below 26.6%), and a 30% chance the rate is above 26.6%. Given prizes reward warranted boldness, and the news sharply increases the likelihood of a 'No' outcome, I am at 30%.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.time_to_resolution: Expected to resolve in mid-to-late 2026 when NCES publishes their 2025 Digest data; current date: December 5, 2025 – thus, ~6 to 12 months remaining.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.perspective_relevance: As a demographic analyst with expertise in population projection standards and enrollment-rate measurement, I am well-positioned to critically assess trends in both the U.S. youth population (18-24) and in higher education enrollment, distinguishing between cyclical fluctuations and structural shifts. I also emphasize the role of migration, international student flows, and institutional response to demographic headwinds in my analysis.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.status_quo: U.S. enrollment rates for 18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges have generally declined since roughly 2011, with incremental drops, acceleration during COVID, partial stabilization post-pandemic, but persistent headwinds from demographics, economics, and policies. The most recent published rate hovered around 27-28% in 2023. The default scenario, if current trends simply continued, would have the rate just at, or slightly above, the 26.6% threshold in 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. The coordinated, sharp, and documented drop in new international student enrollment (-17% YoY)—especially during the main intake window—represents a direct and outsized cut in four-year college headcount, disproportionately affecting the denominator in this ratio. Since these students cluster in four-year programs and often count towards official NCES statistics, a sudden multi-percent fall could alone push the overall rate below the threshold.

Slightly increases probability. The quantitative decline in the 18-24-year-old cohort (the 'demographic cliff') proceeds gradually; schools compete harder for fewer students, which can help the numerator (schools lower standards, boost aid, make applications easier), at least partially offsetting headwinds.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: College Admission Easing & Institutional Retention Strategies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability. Colleges, responding to the applicant shortages, broaden access (waived fees, direct admission offers, rolling deadlines, reduced academic standards). These counteract declining interest to some degree and can buffer total enrollment, particularly in public and non-selective four-year institutions.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic Attitude Shifts on Value of College
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. Domestic demand for four-year college—driven by cost doubts and poor ROI for non-STEM fields—is under sustained challenge. Public trust is eroding, graduation within four years is low, and only 22% consider college worth it if borrowing is required. This creates a slow but steady drag on enrollment among U.S. natives.

Modestly decreases probability. Federal research and education funding is being slashed under the new Trump administration, affecting the resources available to many four-year institutions. This creates additional institutional instability and limits expansion/admissions efforts.

Increases probability slightly. The NCES data is usually finalized after internal estimation and may smooth some of the annual shocks. Additionally, some deferrals (especially international) could be counted in ways that mitigate the headline drop.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.no_scenario: A NO outcome occurs if the combination of the steep 2025 international enrollment collapse (driven by visa delays, denials, and global supply-side competition) subtracts enough students to more than offset colleges' efforts to increase domestic yield—pulling the 18-24 enrollment rate below 26.6%. This could be compounded if the U.S. birth dearth of the late 2000s-2010s hits the denominator, domestic students opt out at higher-than-expected rates, and schools reach their limits in admissions flexibility.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.yes_scenario: A YES outcome occurs if institutional measures to ease admissions and financial barriers (waivers, rolling admission, more scholarships) succeed in recruiting more domestic students than expected, cushioning the loss of international enrollees. If the demographic dip in 18-24 population is not as steep as feared or more students delay entry but still enroll eventually, plus a smoother-than-expected NCES reporting process, then the rate remains above 26.6%.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.final_reasoning: The 2025 news signal is distinctly negative, especially around international enrollment—a 17% drop after earlier declines, with explicit links to visa barriers, administrative backlogs, and geopolitical deterrents. International students contribute disproportionately to enrollment counts at four-year institutions, and the falloff appears too rapid for domestic pools to compensate (particularly as colleges have already been lowering standards for years). Domestic trust in college is at historic lows, and financial/policy headwinds persist. Even with extensive institutional countermeasures, the scale and directness of the international shortfall threaten to pull the rate under 26.6% for the first time. While measurement conventions and one-time smoothing could blunt some effect, on balance the probability is now below even odds for Caplan. Given all considered, though, it's not extremely unlikely—there’s still a solid chance the rate hovers just above the line due to aggressive recruitment of domestic students. But the base rate, accentuated by sharp recent news, pushes this downward.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.time_to_resolution: Approximately 12-13 months until official NCES data for Fall 2025 is published (typically released in late 2026).
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US Social Policy with a focus on Pell Grants and Student Aid, I have deep insight into enrollment drivers among US 18-24-year-olds, both domestic and international, as well as institutional dependence on tuition, effects of economic cycles, financial aid trends, and the impact of policy shocks on higher ed enrollment data. This allows careful calibration of base rates versus the unprecedented developments in late 2024-2025—especially policy reversals on international student visas and recent economic headwinds.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.status_quo: Historically, the enrollment rate of 18-24-year-olds in 4-year colleges has drifted downward slightly from its 29.9% baseline in 2015, but has not yet breached a 10% absolute decline (i.e., it has not fallen to or below 26.6%). Without dramatic new shocks, the rate should hover just above the 26.6% mark, making Caplan’s win slightly more likely in a steady state.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases the probability of Caplan winning. Multiple sources report a historic 17% drop in new international undergrad enrollment for Fall 2025 due to visa delays and restrictive policy, hitting the highest-paying, 4-year-college-attending segment hardest. International students are disproportionately enrolled in 4-year programs and punch above their weight in raising overall enrollment rates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic Demographic Trough and Enrollment Trends
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately decreases probability. The pool of US 18-year-olds entering college is shrinking: US high school grads are declining, and college enrollment rates fell 8.4% from the 2010 peak (per The Conversation). Demographic headwinds are entrenched, reducing supply even if demand persists.

Slightly increases probability. Many colleges are aggressively lowering admissions barriers, waiving fees, offering auto-admit and direct admit programs, plus scholarships to boost yield (Los Angeles Times). These efforts blunt but do not fully reverse the overall enrollment downtrend—colleges are squeezing the marginal domestic applicant harder.

Mixed/slight decrease. Normally recessions increase college enrollment, but the 2025 labor market is weakening (see InvestorPlace: layoffs, wage stagnation, student debt delinquencies). However, K-shaped recovery and high opportunity costs for non-college labor can offset this. Overall, the effect is ambiguous but tends negative due to eroding consumer confidence and college’s perceived ROI.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Degree Value Skepticism, Media, and Policy Backlash
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slight decrease. Gallup and Pew show dwindling belief in the value of 4-year college—only 22% of Americans believe it’s worth it if debt-financed. New regulations and the 'money-back guarantee' debate may deter some risk-averse students, though this likely plays out more in coming years than in 2025 enrollment.

Barely moves probability. There are no major new expansions or contractions in federal student aid in 2025, aside from heightened competition for limited funds amid falling enrollment and higher tuition discounts. Aid as a backstop has been stable and does not offset lost international enrollment.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.no_scenario: Visa disruptions, persistent hostile visa and immigration policy, a 17%+ drop in new international students (with Chinese and Indian numbers dropping sharply), and a weak US labor market combine with a shrinking domestic pool—despite colleges' recruitment efforts, the 4-year college enrollment rate among 18-24-year-olds drops to 26.6% or below. US colleges miss thousands of full-pay international students; domestic enrollment continues its slow slide; the rate dips below the 10% decline threshold Caplan set.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.yes_scenario: Universities' relaxed admissions, open-door practices, and aggressive recruitment—plus late-year improvements in visa processing, allowing some recovery among international students—keep the aggregate enrollment rate just above the 26.6% bar, despite all headwinds. The number lands at 26.7% or higher, giving Caplan the narrowest of wins.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.final_reasoning: The base rate is that US 4-year college enrollment rates have declined gradually, but not rapidly enough to cross the 26.6% threshold absent a crisis. However, the combination of a truly exceptional collapse in new international student enrollment (~17% drop—largest ever), exacerbated by Trump administration visa crackdowns, and persistent domestic demographic decline, push the probability below 50%. While colleges have made major efforts to relax admissions and boost domestic numbers, these cannot fully offset the abrupt shock to the international pipeline (Chinese and Indians account for the majority of international undergraduates) and the US population dip. The post-pandemic bounce is over; data suggest Fall 2025 is the most hostile year for international students in a decade, and domestic skepticism about degree value further clouds the outlook. While it is possible that emergency recruitment, late visa processing fixes, and resilient domestic applications inch the rate above 26.6%, current evidence is heavily weighted toward a near-miss for Caplan. Still, as of December 2025 and with possible late-reported enrollment adjustments, an outcome slightly above 26.6% is not impossible, keeping this from being an extreme call. My best justified forecast is that the probability Bryan Caplan wins is lower than base rate, but not vanishingly so.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).time_to_resolution: Approximately 1 year until the release of relevant NCES data in late 2026, which will reflect 2025 enrollment rates.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).perspective_relevance: As an economist with expertise in Human Capital Theory, I critically assess drivers of educational enrollment by analyzing the evolving perceived and actual returns to higher education investment under structural economic, social, and policy shifts. I focus on endogenous responses to labor market changes, demographic headwinds, and internationalization, integrating forward-looking risk factors that are particularly salient in the current context.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).status_quo: In recent decades, four-year college enrollment rates for U.S. 18–24-year-olds have remained relatively stable or slightly declining, with the 2015 rate at 29.9%. Prior to 2025, rates hovered above 27%. The prevailing trend reflects steady overall population but softness in new student inflows, with international enrollment acting as a buffer.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Significant decrease in probability. Visa processing failures in 2025 have led to a 17% drop in new international enrollments, and overall international student numbers are down sharply, particularly among major contributors like India and China. This is a material negative shock for total four-year enrollments, given heavy reliance on full-paying international undergraduates to sustain or raise rates. While many international students are at the graduate level, the decline is impactful for undergraduate numbers at the margin.

Moderate decrease in probability. The number of 18-year-olds and recent high school graduates is declining due to demographic trends, causing colleges to compete harder for a shrinking pool—a dynamic consistent with a falling denominator and likely declining numerator for four-year undergraduate enrollments, even as acceptance rates rise.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perceived Value and Return on Human Capital Investment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderate decrease in probability. Societal skepticism about the value of college (only 22% see it worth cost if financed by loans) undercuts demand, especially as wage outcomes diverge across majors and debt burdens loom. This inhibits new domestic enrollments and increases dropout risk.

Minor increase in probability. U.S. four-year colleges are actively easing application processes, expanding financial aid, extending deadlines, and using price discrimination to admit marginal students, seeking to maintain headcounts despite lower demand. These efforts can buffer declines but cannot fully offset structural headwinds, especially from abroad.

Slight decrease in probability. Rate cuts have limited effect owing to K-shaped wealth effects and labor market disruption by automation and AI; meanwhile, federal funding cuts and tightening immigration policy further constrain institutions' flexibility to incentivize enrollment.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).no_scenario: Continued decline in international enrollment is not offset by domestic increases. Visa problems, negative perception of U.S. political/social environment, and demographic headwinds result in a 2025 four-year college enrollment rate for 18–24-year-olds falling to or below 26.6%. Institutional countermeasures—such as easier admissions and more aid—prove insufficient, and the loss of high-paying international undergraduates materially shrinks total enrollment.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).yes_scenario: Visa processing issues are resolved rapidly enough for international enrollments to rebound mid-year; domestic enrollments stabilize due to aggressive recruitment, easier admission, and expanded aid. Demographic headwinds are cushioned by schools delaying graduation or boosting retention. The cumulative effect is that the enrollment rate is sustained just above the 26.6% threshold in the 2025 data.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).final_reasoning: A base rate analysis suggests that, until 2023, the enrollment rate had been marginally above the 26.6% threshold. However, the 2025 environment introduces acute, compounding shocks: a 17% drop in new international enrollees, reported overall 8.4% decline from peak (with further slippage likely for 2025), and highly negative topline news from major feeder countries. Domestic demand is softening due to skepticism regarding the value of college and demographic shrinkage. Aggressive institutional responses may blunt some of the decline, but the unparalleled nature of the international student collapse, heavy reliance on that segment for marginal seats, and ongoing labor market disruption all point to a likely breach of the 10% threshold versus 2015. Human capital theory predicts that in an environment of falling returns (real and perceived), and with negative exogenous policy shocks, enrollment rates will drop.

Economics (Signaling Theory).time_to_resolution: Approximately 1-4 months (pending release and/or tally of NCES Digest 2025 enrollment tables in early 2026; Caplan may comment before formal NCES publication).
Economics (Signaling Theory).perspective_relevance: Economics (Signaling Theory) offers insight into the incentives underpinning college enrollment, especially the signaling value of degrees versus their intrinsic human capital development. Dramatic swings in perceived signaling value due to economic, political, or policy shocks can rapidly alter enrollment patterns, especially at the margin. This perspective is crucial now as both domestic demographic headwinds and acute international enrollment disruptions threaten historical baselines. Assessing institutional and student response to these incentives is central to predicting status quo persistence or sudden breaks.
Economics (Signaling Theory).status_quo: The status quo, if nothing changed from the recent past, is that the four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds remains above 26.6% (having been 29.9% in 2015). While the decade has seen gradual decline, recent years have generally seen slow decrement, not precipitous collapse, suggesting the rate remains above the cut threshold on inertia unless significant external shocks emerge.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases the probability. Reports indicate a 17% drop in new international student enrollment for 2025, driven primarily by catastrophic delays in U.S. student visa processing and a hostile environment for foreign students under the Trump administration. International students disproportionately fill seats in four-year colleges, and their rapid retreat removes a vital segment—especially since most pay full tuition supporting institution's budgets.

Modestly decreases the probability. Lower numbers of high school graduates have begun to effect U.S. domestic enrollment figures, with federal data citing an 8.4% drop in total enrollment since the 2010 peak. This pressure is now being acutely felt as colleges scramble for applicants and admit weaker candidates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Collegiate price discrimination and institutional incentives
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Partially increases the probability. Many private colleges will do nearly anything to fill seats—waiving application fees, lowering standards, offering scholarships, pushing direct admissions, and pursuing nontraditional and international students. These strategies exert positive pressure on maintaining headcounts, forestalling a crash below the 26.6% mark.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Intensive negative signaling and declining degree value
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases the probability. Survey data shows the perceived value of a college degree is shrinking: only 22% of Americans think college is worth the cost if loans are involved. This degradation in the degree’s signaling power could, over time, erode marginal enrollment, but dramatic, sudden drops have not historically occurred without recession or major policy change.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Alternative education credentials and labor market evolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally decreases the probability. The rise of alternative pathways (bootcamps, certifications, apprenticeships) and a labor market less responsive to traditional four-year signals could pull some would-be enrollees directly into the workforce, but the effect is currently mild relative to the overall scale of four-year enrollment.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base-rate inertia in the U.S. 18-24 four-year college enrollment rate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly increases the probability. Historical time series suggest a slow, gradual decline, not a collapse; the prior 10% drop over a decade precedent would place the rate just at the cut-off, but the most severe episodic drops (e.g., pandemic) have not caused the rate to fall much faster than trend.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent institutional over-enrollment efforts and emergency measures
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases the probability. The rapid expansion of direct admissions and aggressive recruitment, as highlighted in news articles, suggest institutions will likely keep domestic rates up, even amid international collapse, to avoid financial and reputational disaster.

Economics (Signaling Theory).no_scenario: A No-resolution occurs if U.S. four-year undergraduate enrollment for 18-24-year-olds falls to 26.6% or below in 2025. The most compelling scenario for this features the cumulative effect of a 17% collapse in new international students, ongoing decline in U.S. high school graduate numbers, and further erosion of the perceived degree value—possibly exacerbated by the economic and policy environment—causing not only international, but also marginal domestic students to forego college. Colleges, overwhelmed by revenue losses and forced to cut programs or close, are unable to backfill international shortfalls domestically even with aggressive recruitment, leading to a sharper-than-normal downturn.
Economics (Signaling Theory).yes_scenario: A Yes-resolution occurs if the four-year enrollment rate stays above 26.6%. In this scenario, while the international drop damages the absolute headcount, most of the effect is at the margin (i.e., new, not continuing, international students) and is partially offset by institutions' extreme efforts to fill seats—eliminating admissions criteria, direct admissions, scholarships, and recruiting non-traditional students. The net effect is a continuation of the gradual downward trend. Domestic students, amid weak job prospects, have not reduced college-going rates sharply, and the base-rate inertia of the post-pandemic years holds. International students returning via new policies late in the year does little to rescue the 2025 fall number but prevents further erosion.
Economics (Signaling Theory).final_reasoning: The acute 2025 international student visa crisis represents the single biggest short-term negative shock to four-year enrollment in recent memory, with new international enrollment collapsing by 17% and overall foreign enrollment dropping for a second consecutive year. Given that international students constitute a substantial portion of four-year enrollees—especially in the 18-24 bracket—this shock is significant. The demographic trend of fewer 18-year-olds adds underlying pressure. However, structural inertia, institutional desperation, and aggressive recruiting suggest institutions are backstopping as much attrition as possible. Historical base rates show glacial decline in college-going rates; only in extraordinary circumstances (e.g., a pandemic or major legislative reformation) do we see cliffs. Even with a 17% annual drop in *new* international students, offset somewhat by continuing and OPT students, and presuming the worst-case no-rebound scenario, the numerical hit—while severe—may not quite drive the overall four-year enrollment rate below the 26.6% betting threshold for 2025, unless domestic enrollment also underperforms expectations. Still, the risk of a negative outcome is now materially higher than in prior years: base rates might suggest 80%+, but after accounting for this year’s unique international collapse, a realistic, signaling-theory informed, bold-yet-supported probability is appropriate between 62% and 72%.

Economics (Demographic Transition).time_to_resolution: Data release expected in mid-to-late 2026, so roughly 7–12 months remain.
Economics (Demographic Transition).perspective_relevance: My expertise in population economics and the demographic transition is directly relevant. College enrollment is structurally linked to population cohorts, labor market conditions, international migration, and evolving incentives—factors shaped by demographics, economics, and policy. As an economist, I can interpret how evolving student-age populations, labor market growth, and macro-level shocks like visa policies or declining birth rates impact aggregate enrollment in higher education, particularly in the critical 18–24 year-old, four-year college segment.
Economics (Demographic Transition).status_quo: The status quo is that in 2015, the 18–24 four-year college enrollment rate was 29.9%. The most recently published data (generally lagging, but recent Digest of Education Statistics tables) showed only steady or modest declines over the past decade. If current trends persist unchanged, enrollment remains slightly above the 26.6% threshold, meaning Caplan wins.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability—U.S. birth rates fell after 2008 and are now reflected in a lower number of 18-years-olds. The 'demographic cliff' is only just beginning to impact incoming undergraduate classes, exerting a gradual but small downward pressure on the enrollment rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor Market and Perceived Value of College
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly negative—Although skepticism about value is rising (only 22% believe a degree is worth it if financed with loans), four-year colleges still attract a large share of those planning tertiary education, and labor market softening may push some toward college as an insurance strategy. However, long-term doubts about value may steer some toward non-college alternatives, slightly decreasing the enrollment rate.

Significantly decreases probability—2025 saw a severe 17% drop in new international student enrollment (across three news sources), driven mostly by a catastrophic State Department visa disruption, with particular declines from India and China. Since international students are heavily overrepresented at four-year universities—even though many are in graduate programs, they meaningfully depress the proportion enrolled overall.

Mildly increases probability—Universities are responding to declining demand with easier admissions, aggressive direct offers, lower standards, and more generous financial aid. This helps 'inflate' the numerator (enrollment) and maintain the rate, as many institutions scrape for marginal students. Net effect is to buffer a potential collapse and keep rates elevated.

Marginally decreases probability—Budget constraints from cuts under Trump increase institutional pressure and could prompt tuition hikes or reduced offerings, discouraging some marginal students, but the timeline is too narrow for deep effects in this cycle.

Negligible to slightly negative—More students consider trades, bootcamps, or immediate employment. Culturally, skepticism towards higher education is up but still a minority view; many families and communities continue to direct the college-bound toward four-year institutions.

Economics (Demographic Transition).no_scenario: The numerator suffers significant attrition from both domestic students (opting out for alternatives, wary of debt and low ROI) and international students (due to catastrophic visa failures and negative perceptions of U.S. receptivity). Demographic headwinds are compounded by further policy missteps, economic malaise, or a sudden, unanticipated event (e.g., another pandemic sub-wave). The four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24 year-olds plunges to 26.6% or lower.
Economics (Demographic Transition).yes_scenario: Despite international losses, domestic 'gap' students—faced with a weak labor market—return to study or stay in school, propped up by easier admissions, greater aid, and institutional desperation to fill seats. Declines in the 18–24 population are offset by higher enrollment rates amongst remaining cohorts, and the rate remains above 26.6%. International losses are proportionally offset by growth or stability among U.S.-born students.
Economics (Demographic Transition).final_reasoning: Enrollment in four-year colleges among 18-24-year-olds has faced sustained pressure from demographics and a catastrophic 2025 international student collapse. However, the numerator for this ratio is buffered by (a) institutional desperation leading to super-easy admissions, (b) labor market cooling nudging some marginal students to stay in or choose college, and (c) the fact that the vast majority of international students (especially Indians, the only growing group) are in graduate programs, while four-year undergrad rates are less dramatically impacted by the sharp visa drop than overall new international enrollments suggest. The denominator (all 18–24-year-olds) is also falling, which could preserve or even buoy the rate. Historically, even with 8–10% declines in total college enrollment since 2010, four-year enrollments have been relatively resilient compared to two-year schools, so the base rate for a >3.3pp drop in a single decade is quite low. Trends have been down, but not at the pace required to push the rate below 26.6%. There’s a real risk this time, given policy shocks, but with institutions working aggressively to counteract declines, and domestic pathways buffered, the most likely outcome remains a rate just above the threshold, meaning Caplan wins, albeit narrowly.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).time_to_resolution: Less than 1 year (The 2025 NCES data on 18-24 year-old four-year college enrollment will be released in early-to-mid 2026, likely after the 2025 fall semester, but the resolution is for the 2025 data year.)
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).perspective_relevance: As an expert in the sociology of status attainment, I focus on how educational pathways—especially access to and persistence in four-year colleges—shape opportunities for socio-economic mobility. I study demographic, structural, and institutional factors influencing who enrolls in college and who does not, as well as historical trends. This insight is highly relevant to projecting U.S. college enrollment rates, particularly in a period of changing demographics, shifting economic returns to education, and international competition.
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).status_quo: The status quo, based on the 2015 NCES data, is a 29.9% enrollment rate for 18-24 year-olds in four-year colleges. The cutoff for Caplan winning is 26.6%, meaning any rate above that means Caplan wins. In recent years, there has been a mild but noticeable decline in overall college enrollment rates, international enrollment volatility, and major headwinds in the higher education sector.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; the 'birth dearth' is lowering the number of high school graduates, and colleges compete harder for a declining pool, but total numbers are falling.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional adaptation (Relaxed admissions, more financial aid, aggressive recruitment)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability; colleges respond to enrollment declines with easier admissions and more aid, helping buffer the rate from sharper drops.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International student enrollment and visa policies
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; a catastrophic 2025 visa processing failure caused a 17% drop in new international students, especially from India and China, which typically make up a substantial share of full-pay four-year college students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perceived return on investment in higher education
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability (but effect is gradual); declining belief in the economic value of a college degree—especially with specific majors—may depress enrollment at the margins, with greater impact in the long run.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Short-term external factors (political, pandemic aftershocks, economic uncertainty)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability modestly; federal funding cuts, stricter immigration policies, and economic uncertainty all create headwinds, but these are partially offset by colleges' incentives to fill seats.

Increases probability briefly; historically, major drops in 4-year college enrollment rates are rare year-on-year unless driven by massive shocks (e.g., a pandemic), so base rate inertia keeps the probability of falling below 26.6% relatively low for a single year.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).no_scenario: The 2025 NCES data shows the rate at or below 26.6%, meaning a greater than 10% drop from 2015. This occurs if domestic enrollment falls sharply due to the shrinking youth cohort and declining perceived value, while the catastrophic 2025 international student visa breakdown is not offset by domestic increases, and four-year colleges cannot fill seats despite aggressive recruitment. The historic decline in international students (especially high-pay groups like Indian and Chinese students) is so severe that not even discounts and outreach salvage the numbers. The rate falls precipitously as a result.
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).yes_scenario: The four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in 2025 remains above 26.6%. This scenario is more likely if the drop in international enrollments, while severe, is cushioned by domestic institutions pulling out all stops to fill seats—lowering admissions barriers, ramping up aid, and targeting domestic non-traditional students. The base rate inertia from previous years keeps the rate above the cutoff, with the enrollment dip being serious but not catastrophic enough to breach the 26.6% trigger. U.S. colleges are able to blunt the enrollment crisis (particularly for four-year, not two-year, colleges) just enough to prevent a >10% decline from 2015.
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).final_reasoning: Given my expertise in status attainment, I place strong weight on the competing dynamics between substantial enrollment shocks—especially from the 17% drop in new international student enrollment and sharp policy changes—and the remarkable institutional adaptability of U.S. four-year colleges. The base rate of a greater than 10% drop over a 10-year period is low, but the alignment of negative factors (shrinking cohort, value skepticism, Trump-era visa policies, catastrophic 2025 State Department failure) is unprecedented, and specifically acute in fall 2025. However, these headwinds may be partially blunted: elite and upper-tier institutions maintain robust demand, domestic recruitment expands, and compensatory measures dilute the sharpest impact. The probability of the enrollment rate dropping less than 10% (i.e., staying above 26.6%) is still over half, but the risk is significant—a far cry from near-certainty. Balancing the historical inertia, the uniquely bad 2025 international student year, and domestic adaptation, I estimate a probability somewhat above 60% that Bryan Caplan wins his bet, but well short of near-certainty.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).time_to_resolution: Less than one month (question resolves upon release of 2025 NCES enrollment data, typically in Dec-Jan).
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in sociology, especially social stratification theory, my perspective enables me to evaluate changes in college enrollment as they relate to shifts in class structure, perceptions of higher education's value, access inequality, and institutional responses to demographic and policy shifts. This background is critical given recent upheavals in international student mobility, economic challenges, and the changing landscape of higher education access, all of which are deeply connected to stratification processes.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).status_quo: From 2015 through 2022, the enrollment rate of American 18-24 year-olds in four-year colleges experienced a modest downward drift, but rates consistently remained above 27%. In 2015, it was 29.9%, and as of the most recent available NCES data (2022), rates were near 27.6%. Declines were gradual barring pandemic volatility. Without major shocks, rates might have stayed just above 26.6% into 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Collapse in new international student enrollment, especially due to 2025 U.S. visa-processing crisis
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. Both news and sector surveys document a 17% YoY decline in new international student enrollment (the sharpest in modern U.S. history), exacerbated by multi-week visa processing halts and broader anti-immigrant policies. International students disproportionately enroll in 4-year colleges and are critical to offsetting flat/falling domestic cohorts.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic headwinds—declining domestic 18-24-year-old population and K-shaped post-pandemic recovery
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. A shrinking pool of high school graduates due to demographic shifts (widely anticipated 'demographic cliff') reduces the numerator. While colleges are fighting for applicants with more aggressive tactics, the denominator (total 18-24-year-olds) may decline slightly less quickly due to immigration, but not enough to fully offset domestic softness.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: University institutional adaptation and 'soft landing' strategies (eg, relaxed admissions, waivers, financial aid, direct admission, post-May recruiting)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability. Sociologically, this demonstrates the resilience and market adaptation of the higher education field: broadening access, lowering requirements, and leveraging price discrimination to fill seats, despite dips in demand. These strategies may buoy the rate by ensuring marginal students still enroll.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Value perception/ROI skepticism among middle and lower classes
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. Declining faith in the economic utility of a degree (only 22% say it’s worth it with loans) particularly affects working-class and lower-middle-class families who bear the most risk. This may lead to more opting out, at the margins, especially from four-year paths.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Intense institutional reliance on international students to stabilize finances
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases sensitivity to international enrollment swings—universities may go extraordinary lengths to keep international rates from crashing further, but evidence suggests 2025 shocks outpaced mitigation attempts.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Differential impact on two-year vs four-year colleges
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed/slightly increases probability for this bet. The overall enrollment drop is steeper in two-year colleges, as financially challenged or skeptical students shift to vocational/shorter options. This can marginally shelter the four-year rate.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).no_scenario: The combined impact of visa processing breakdown leads to a sharper-than-expected drop in international four-year enrollments, and muted domestic interest—despite intense recruitment efforts—results in the rate for 18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges dipping to 26.5% or below, breaking through the Caplan bet ceiling.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).yes_scenario: Colleges’ aggressive tactics to attract and enroll both domestic and international students—direct admission, fee waivers, expanded support and financial aid—succeed sufficiently to keep the decline shallow. International numbers fall, but not enough to offset these interventions and demographic softness, resulting in a rate that remains just above 26.6%.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).final_reasoning: Base rates from NCES data suggest a slow, steady decline, with recent pre-pandemic years showing remarkable resilience—even COVID only knocked several tenths of a percentage point off rates. However, the confluence in fall 2025 of: (1) a historic and abrupt (>15%) drop in new international student arrivals across all types of institutions due to a catastrophic US visa-processing failure, (2) growing competition from other countries for international students, (3) declining domestic population, and (4) persistent doubts among working-class families about the ROI of college, all suggest a sharper decline than status quo projections. While institutions are pulling out all the stops to maintain enrollment—softening admissions, financial aid boosts, waivers—structural constraints and the magnitude of the visa collapse (which operate on the relevant numerator) loom large, especially given international students' outsize role in sustaining four-year rates. The most current news (Dec 2025) suggests the 17% international drop and a roughly 8% total undergraduate enrollment decline since the 2010 peak. The threshold for Caplan’s win—>26.6%—is now in jeopardy. My rough model suggests it's most likely the published 2025 data will come in at or just below 26.6%, with significant downside risk for Caplan due to timing and abruptness of recent shocks. My sociology/stratification lens leads me to put added weight on policy and class-based drivers of sudden enrollment change—this year is not just a gentle continuation of prior trends. Therefore, I will forecast a sub-50% chance (Caplan loses is now the slight favorite), but with some uncertainty given universities' historic adaptability and possible lagged effects in denominator shifts.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.time_to_resolution: Less than 1 month (NCES Digest high-level enrollment rates for previous fall are typically published in mid-to-late December or early January; public statements by Caplan may precede that by days or weeks.)
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Education Studies with emphasis on Tinto's Student Integration Model, I bring a systems-level understanding of how student integration (academic, social, and institutional) and broader environmental dynamics affect college persistence and, by extension, institutional enrollment. This allows me to specially interpret not just numeric trends, but also the behavioral and structural drivers that modulate student decisions and institutional practices.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.status_quo: Recent years have witnessed a gradual but persistent decline in undergraduate enrollment rates among US 18-24 year-olds. In 2015, the 4-year college enrollment rate for this group was 29.9%. To win his bet, Caplan requires the 2025 rate to remain above 26.6% (no greater than a 10% relative decline). As of recent years (pre-2025), the rate hovered in the upper 20%s with incremental annual drops. Without exogenous shocks (e.g., policy changes, major economic disruption, or a sudden change in public perception), the rate would likely have fallen but marginally, possibly keeping above the 26.6% line. However, several acute shocks have occurred in 2025, most notably the visa crisis sharply reducing international enrollments.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability: The 17% YoY collapse in new international student enrollments due to visa processing failures/disincentives is an extreme negative shock. Since international students composed a major growth area for 4-year institutions and made up a substantial (though minority) share of the 18-24 US college population, this directly reduces overall rates. Even considering not all international students are 18-24, the size and abruptness of this collapse—especially in context of noncitizen inclusion in the NCES denominator—risks the rate falling below the threshold.

Moderately decreases probability: Ongoing drops in the number of high school graduates and the total 18-24-year-old cohort reduce the pool for 4-year college entry, reflected in easier admissions and direct recruitment strategies. Some of this effect is buffered by colleges lowering barriers, but with fewer young people outright, the numerator (enrolled) falls in step with the denominator.

Modestly increases probability: Tinto’s framework would predict that, faced with declining applications/enrollments and academic standards, institutions pursue aggressive yield-maximization (waiving fees, auto-admit offers, later deadlines, broad outreach). While this boosts marginal populations, it cannot fully offset systemic external shocks (international collapse, demographic contraction, policy headwinds). Still, these efforts marginally prop up enrollment among domestic students.

Slightly decreases probability: With only 22% of Americans viewing college as worth its cost if financed through loans, pressures on the college-for-all norm are intensifying. More 18-24-year-olds are questioning higher ed's value proposition and opting for alternatives, compounded by negative labor market trends post-pandemic (delinquencies, soft job market, automation concerns, rising skepticism).

Negligible for this question: Much of the current international data reflect an OPT-driven increase in total international headcount, but since the bet is about 18-24-year-olds in 4-year programs (not OPT, which skews older), this buffer does not apply directly.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.no_scenario: After a multi-year slide, combined effects of the 2025 international student visa debacle and worsening demographics push the share of 18-24s enrolled in 4-year colleges under 26.6%. Notably, the collapse in new international undergraduate students (17% drop), especially from China and India, both shrinks the numerator and increases the denominator (as noncitizens are generally in the denominator). Tinto’s model suggests institutions attempt to integrate as many as possible, but overwhelmed support systems, skepticism about value, and external barriers overwhelm their efforts. The 2025 NCES data show 25.5%-26.5%. Caplan loses the bet.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.yes_scenario: Despite deep losses among new international students, institutions' aggressive retention/yield tactics work well enough to keep enrollment rates from dropping precipitously: application waivers, direct admission, post-May recruiting, and tuition discounts boost marginal domestic numbers. Meanwhile, most current-enrolled international students remain due to graduate/OPT programs, and non-international, traditional students persist amid a weak labor market (encouraging more to stay in school as jobs grow scarce). The rate drops slightly, but remains above 26.6%—say, 27.0-27.5%. Caplan wins.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.final_reasoning: The sharp and publicized collapse of new international student enrollment (down 17% in one year, with additional declines from 2024) is a historic negative shock, the largest since COVID. It is acute, especially affecting the most tuition-dependent private institutions and major public flagships reliant on international undergraduates (especially from China and India, both mentioned as declining >4%). Demographic contraction and low perceived value further apply downward pressure. While institutions have pulled all available levers—streamlining admissions, financial incentives, and aggressive yield-management—the magnitude and suddenness of this year's international shortfall and ongoing domestic headwinds likely outpace their compensatory effect. Tinto's model would expect that student integration and institutional effort can modestly mitigate, but not fully offset, sector-wide exogenous shocks on this scale. Recent base rates (NCES, IPEDS) show a slow glide path, but the abruptness and depth of the international student shortfall is a discontinuity, tipping the odds below 50%. The only offsetting argument is that some reporting on the international drop may overstate its impact on the 18-24-year-old, 4-year college denominator, but the numbers suggest the drop is real, very recent, and geographically broad. Unless there is an unanticipated last-minute statistical buffer in the NCES tally, Caplan is likely to lose.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.time_to_resolution: Approximately 12 months, as the question will resolve after the release of 2025 NCES data (likely late 2026), but the bet references the state of fall 2025 enrollment and the public acknowledgement by Bryan Caplan.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Education Studies with a focus on Access and Participation, I am well-positioned to interpret shifting patterns in college enrollment, policies affecting domestic and international student access, and structural changes in college admissions and financing. This background allows for nuanced weighting of factors such as demographic trends, visa policies, public attitudes toward college value, and institutional strategies to maintain or expand participation among 18-24 year olds.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.status_quo: The most recent (pre-2025) data showed the college enrollment rate for 18-24 year-olds in 4-year institutions was declining but had not dropped below 26.6%. Even with recent declines, the rate in the early 2020s hovered between ~27-30%. If nothing extraordinary changed, a drop below 26.6% in 2025 would be historically large and notable.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases: The 17% drop in new international enrollment—driven by visa delays and negative perceptions—directly reduces total 4-year enrollment. This is especially impactful as international students are disproportionately 4-year enrollees at research and elite institutions, which prop up the overall rate. A sharp, one-year drop could easily tip the rate below 26.6% if not offset by domestic trends.

Decreases: The overall pool of 18-24 year olds has been shrinking for several years, exacerbating competition for students and leading to a lower aggregate enrollment rate. The 'demographic cliff' in high school graduates is now materializing, as noted by rising acceptance rates and colleges struggling to fill seats.

Increases: U.S. colleges have responded to shrinking applicant pools with aggressive recruitment, simplified applications, test-optional policies, and direct/automatic admission offers. These measures can help keep domestic enrollment rates from falling as fast as demographics would otherwise dictate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perceived Value of College and Political Headwinds
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases: The perceived ROI of a 4-year degree is at record lows (only 22% think it’s worth it if loans are required) and there is increasing scrutiny of cost and employment outcomes. Coupled with federal funding cuts and political debate about fraud and refunds, this may discourage marginal students from enrolling and could accelerate attrition, especially among lower-income youth.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Budget Constraints and Financial Sustainability of Colleges
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases: Many institutions are losing federal funds and seeing budget strain from lost tuition. Some cut programs or even contemplate closures, which can reduce available 4-year seats and create negative feedback on enrollment. Private colleges in particular may be at acute risk.

Decreases (Reinforces earlier factor): Besides the sudden visa processing collapse, ongoing policy unpredictability (interview pauses, new vetting) continues to create uncertainty, potentially delaying or deterring even those international students who try to enroll.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Enrollment Base Rate and Institutional Adaptation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases: Historically, U.S. 4-year college enrollment rates for 18-24 year-olds have been resilient—even during COVID. Institutions have deep incentives (including survival) to keep rates above historic lows, and creative adaptation tends to blunt some shocks. Most private colleges will lower standards and discount tuition if needed to fill seats.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.no_scenario: A 'No' scenario (Caplan loses; rate is 26.6% or below) would result if the combined effect of the international student collapse and the shrinking domestic high-school cohort outweigh institutional countermeasures. For example, the 17% drop in new international students is not offset by a rise in domestic enrollment or retention, perhaps because negative perceptions and the poor labor market outlook further depress demand. Domestic students may also opt out of college for immediate work amid economic uncertainty, and a wave of smaller private college closures or consolidations could shrink seat availability in 4-year programs. If the 2025 data show, e.g., that the full-time enrollment rate is 26.2%, this would be the scenario—even if most of the drop is due to international factors.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.yes_scenario: A 'Yes' scenario (Caplan wins; rate is above 26.6%) would occur if the domestic applicant pool, bolstered by aggressive recruitment, simplified admissions, fee waivers, and continued price discrimination, keeps domestic enrollment flat or only slightly down, cushioning the impact of international declines. Some lost international headcount could be offset by increases in graduate or online program enrollments, or via improved late-in-the-cycle policy adjustments (e.g., expedited visas from October 2025) minimizing year-end damage. Institutions may succeed in recruiting from underrepresented or lower-income populations via financial aid and flexible admissions, maintaining the enrollment rate above the critical threshold.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.final_reasoning: Base rates suggest that year-over-year drops of more than 1-2% in the four-year college enrollment rate are rare absent severe shocks (such as COVID-19). However, the confluence of the international student collapse (-17% in new international enrollees, driven by visa delays), ongoing domestic demographic decline, loss of perceived college value, and budget stress (including federal funding cuts) all present an unusually powerful headwind for 2025. The recent news describes a catastrophic and systemic disruption to international admissions, which are critical to keeping some 4-year programs viable and sustaining overall rates. Even robust institutional countermeasures may not be sufficient to completely offset the double whammy of a rapidly shrinking international cohort and stagnant or declining domestic numbers. Nevertheless, the resilience and adaptability of the U.S. higher education system, along with unprecedented recruitment efforts and simplified application processes, could mitigate the effect enough to barely keep the rate above the threshold—especially if the denominator (18-24 year-old population) does not shrink faster than expected. I regard the situation as precariously balanced, but the scale and abruptness of international losses argue for a moderate-to-high probability that the threshold will be breached. I estimate the probability that Caplan will win the bet (that is, enrollment rate >26.6%) at 35%. The scenario is not certain but risk of 'No' is now substantially higher than in any previous year, due primarily to factors unique to 2025.

HigherEducationPolicyAnalysisIpedsEnroll.response: I have to call out Economics(Signaling Theory) for being too sanguine and underweighting the direct structural effects of the international student collapse. Yes, there's inertia in these high-level rates and institutions are scrambling, but the 17% falloff in *new* international enrollees is a direct hit to the numerator, and not something a year of desperate institutional outreach can backfill, given demographic contraction on the domestic front. Throwing around a 62-72% likelihood for Caplan to win feels like a blinkered overreliance on base rates and slow-moving trends, instead of absorbing the news flow: this is the deepest, most universal negative shock since the pandemic, but without the policy supports and recovery bounce. If anything, signaling discounts the very labor market and value pressures that are eroding the draw and return on higher ed, which even Caplan himself would probably concede. There’s little historical precedent for a single-year international loss of this velocity NOT manifesting in the final rate. You want bold? The only justifiable bold take is downside risk, not optimism. This isn’t a half-step drop; it’s the ground opening underneath us. If the number is over 26.6%, it’s a razor’s edge, not a comfortable landing.

HigherEducationPolicyAnalysisPostseconda.response: Signaling theorists, you’re running on autopilot from pre-2025 data. You say base rates show 'glacial decline,' but this is not statistical noise in a sea of slow-moving trends—this is an unprecedented, externally imposed cliff-drop in international enrollment, reinforced by a softening domestic market and eroded perceived value. You wave off the international hit by invoking institutional desperation and inertia, but you ignore that international new admits—especially undergrads, especially Chinese/Indian applicants—form the only real growth margin left in the four-year sector. The whole structure of signaling theory is that demand dries up if the signal's value drops, so why suddenly lean on inertia and recruitment wizardry? Are you seriously going to claim that schools competing for a shrinking domestic pool, while bleeding the only segment willing to pay full fare, results in a two-thirds chance Caplan ekes out a win? The only signaling going on here is a loud red flag for an enrollment crash. Your 'bold' range is the real risk—boldly wrong.

DemographicAnalysisCohortComponentMethod.response: Economics(Demographic Transition), your optimism is pure wishcasting, ignoring the empirically demonstrable importance of international undergrads as the margin-holders of recent four-year rates. You assert, blandly, that the denominator shrinkage will buoy the rate—but we've run these math exercises year after year: even a shrinking denominator can't save the numerator when there's a historic, single-year drop of 17% in new international enrollments. You downplay the impact by invoking labor market cooling and loose admissions, yet direct NCES/IPEDS trends show that when international intake falls off a cliff, domestic backfilling simply doesn't materialize at scale, especially during a demographic contraction and with widespread skepticism about college ROI. The idea that 'institutional desperation' overrides policy and visa catastrophe is a classic error of linear adjustment reasoning in a system experiencing exogenous shock. Demographic transition theory requires recognizing the limits of compensatory behavior—when one pipeline collapses, it doesn’t instantly re-balance. Betting that Caplan will 'win, albeit narrowly' is a perfect example of overfitting to gradual-trend thinking in a year defined by sharp discontinuity. We’re demographers; the cohort math is clear: the shock to the numerator is greater than anything seen since COVID, and without a bounceback year after, inertia cuts the other way.

DemographicAnalysisPopulationProjectionS.response: Let’s put aside the wishy-washy hedging for a second—‘institutional desperation,’ ‘denominator shrinkage,’ and ‘labor market cooling’ are crumbs when faced with a 17% annual collapse in new international undergrad enrollment and a two-year double-digit drop among core feeder nations. Demographic transition theory doesn’t mean ‘denominator shrinkage magically props up every ratio regardless of what’s happening to the numerator.’ The NCES rate is driven by actual enrollment, not hypothetical admissions generosity. Domestic backfill in a context of widespread skepticism, affordability fears, and birth dearth is an empty hope. The last decade’s inertia is shattered in years with exogenous shocks—see: COVID. And this time, there isn’t even pandemic-level policy accommodation to cushion the hit. Your forecast puts way too much faith in the sector’s adaptability and completely underestimates the direct, near-immediate numerical impact of international fallout on the published NCES outcome. Caplan squeaks by? It’d take measurement luck or a reporting fudge, not real-world enrollment behavior. This is the year when the supposed demographic buffer fails.

UsSocialPolicyPellGrantAndStudentAidPoli.response: Enough with the denominator magic trick! 'Denominator decline'—the shrinking pool of 18-24-year-olds—was already humming in the background for years, and it hasn’t been enough to keep four-year rates aloft through gentler declines, much less a shock of this magnitude. You lean far too heavily on lag, inertia, and historical resilience, ignoring that sudden double-digit international losses are not just 'big rounding errors' but direct, quantifiable holes in the numerator that NO level of 'easier admissions' or labor market nudging has ever filled, let alone during an era of plummeting perceived value. Let's get real: US colleges' policy gymnastics don't manifest extra tens of thousands of qualified domestic enrollees when the high school grad pool is itself tanking, and doubts about ROI are at an all-time high. You treat international undergrad new admits as if their collapse is mostly noise and play up that 'the vast majority' are grads—conveniently sidestepping headlines about which subgroups actually drive the marginal difference in the 18-24, four-year bucket Caplan bet on. Historically, *any* sharp exogenous multi-percentage-point drop coincides with an abrupt headline impact on the NCES rate—that's what basic component analysis shows. The idea that Caplan remains favored because of inertia and a little numerator/denominator buffering is statistical fantasy, not empirical demographic reasoning.
