EconomicsHumanCapitalTheory.response: Unlike the demographic Pollyannas and signaling diehards, Sociology(Status Attainment Research) at least recognizes the unprecedented alignment of structural shocks—demographic cliff, catastrophic collapse in international admits, and battered perceptions of college value—against the historic adaptability of U.S. higher ed. Their 62% probability is optimistic for my taste, but it's not rooted in denialism. They get the core dynamic: the 2025 environment isn't a mere continuation of inertia or a blip in slow-mo decline, but a full-spectrum, multi-front assault on the numerator that could overwhelm even robust institutional adaptation. Status attainment theory is spot-on in warning that this isn’t the year for defaults and glacial trends; any resilience will be fought for inch by inch. They don't gloss over the fact that elite institutions will weather the storm better, nor do they claim compensatory recruitment is a panacea. I’d argue for a still lower probability Caplan wins, but at least this is social science tuned to present shocks, not past comfort.

EconomicsSignalingTheory.response: Sociology (Social Stratification Theory) finally brings the necessary sense of risk and discontinuity to this forecast. They aren’t mesmerized by base rates or the illusion of infinite institutional adaptability; instead, they rightly foreground abrupt, class-inflected enrollment shocks with tangible empirical anchors—a >15% sudden drop in international arrivals, persistent skepticism among working-class families, and the limitations of even the most desperate administrative policies in blunting systemic shocks. The best part: they acknowledge universities’ efforts, but correctly see them as countercurrents, not as magic wands that erase a collapsed international pipeline. Their probability is sub-50%, mapping perfectly to the uncertainty of policy shocks on class and sectoral resilience, and avoids both doomerism and Pollyanna optimism. Social stratification matters most during stress moments like 2025, and this forecaster nails the analytic weighting by putting risk front and center.

EconomicsDemographicTransition.response: Let’s talk demographic transition, because your optimism borders on denial. You spin denominator shrinkage as a magic propellant for the ratio—which, sure, *helps* in a static world—but 2025 isn’t static; it’s a demolition derby. A 17% collapse in *new* international undergrads doesn’t get patched over by a handful of late domestic admits or softer labor markets, especially when the high school grad population is simultaneously sliding and perception of college value is battered. 'Institutional desperation' and applying Band-Aid admissions only go so far (see: prior years’ ineffectiveness during lesser shocks); this time, the magnitude of international attrition is on another level. The theory falls flat if you pretend compositional and pipeline shocks aren't the dominant force. This year, the numerator drop isn’t a rounding error, it’s the headline. Caplan ekes out a win only if NCES fumbles measurement or some miracle confidence rebound happens in the final weeks—not because the underlying demographic or economic story supports it. You’re clinging to trendlines in a hurricane.

SociologyStatusAttainmentResearch.response: Demographic transition optimism has gone off the rails when you cling to denominator shrinkage as if it offers safe haven in a storm of numerator chaos. Institutional desperation—easier admits, labor market nudges—can only do so much in a year when the lifeblood of full-pay, four-year enrollment (new international students) has just been decimated by historic visa disaster. Look, the enrollment rate is a function of absolute numbers: when you lose tens of thousands of new international undergrads overnight, *while* the domestic college-bound cohort shrinks and skepticism about college value surges, it is simply statistical fantasy to think you can backfill the gap. The denominator's slow descent cannot outpace a numerator cliff drop. This isn't a year where marginal statistical drift gets you through; it's a year where the whole sector is gasping for air. Your model underestimates the immediacy and severity of a rare, exogenous, administratively driven panic that colleges cannot recruit their way out of—certainly not at the scale needed to protect the 26.6% threshold. The lesson of status attainment research? The structural shocks always punch through individual or institutional adaptation faster than anyone expects.

SociologySocialStratificationTheory.response: Signaling theory, wake up: you're whistling past the graveyard on this one. Your bet on 'structural inertia' and 'aggressive recruiting' is a textbook case of wishful thinking when the math is this ugly. A 17% drop in new international undergrads is a body blow to the numerator, and colleges haven't recruited their way out of smaller slumps, let alone this. Your confidence in historical glacial declines is misplaced—what's happening now is not a slow bleed, but an arterial spray. Labor market signaling doesn't outweigh logistics: if your marginal applicants can't get into the country, if the ROI looks worse every year, and if the only demographic that's been plugging enrollment holes is suddenly AWOL, then 'reserve adaptation' is powerless. The history of sharp exogenous shocks—COVID, 9/11, Trump-era bans—shows measurable, near-immediate effects in reported data, not offset in a single cycle by magical inertia. This isn't a close shave in Caplan's favor; it's the kind of convergence of shocks that could put the rate under 26.6% for the first time. You're not being bold—you're ignoring the scoreboard.

EducationStudiesTintoStudentIntegration.response: Your narrative of denominator shrinkage acting as a life raft in a year of catastrophic numerator loss is a misreading of enrollment arithmetic and Tinto’s sociological logic. Institutional desperation and easier admissions cannot summon domestic 18-24-year-olds out of thin air when the high school pipeline is already contracting and value perceptions are nosediving. You sidestep the direct hit of a 17% new international undergrad collapse—which, per NCES reporting conventions, guts the numerator for this metric—by dwelling on labor market cooling and institutional resilience. But these forces have historically yielded incremental, not compensatory, gains. When systemic integration breaks down—be it through visa barriers, international pipeline decimation, or sector-wide shocks—Tinto shows the integration machinery simply can’t deliver retention or recruitment at required scale. This is not a slow burn; it’s a sector-wide rupture, and to forecast Caplan as likely to squeak by is to fundamentally misunderstand both math and organizational constraints in the face of acute exogenous trauma.

EducationStudiesAccessAndParticipationRe.response: Signaling theorists, you've built your 68% on a teetering scaffold of historical inertia—conveniently overlooking that 2025 is the year all the usual signals went haywire. When your whole framework depends on students perceiving 4-year enrollment as a productive, prestige-y signal and the policy environment blocks tens of thousands from ever setting foot on campus, the signal has no chance to function. The magnitude of the international collapse is a real-world, not theoretical, supply shock—and the denominator games and institutional 'desperation' simply can’t recruit ghost students. Those who could be recruited (domestic marginal admits) are shrinking in both number and willingness, thanks to demographic decline and the perception of a questionable college payoff. Prior sharp disruptions (see: COVID, post-9/11, prior visa shocks) all produced sudden, measurable drops, and none of those occurred alongside such a bleak international and domestic outlook. You talk big about inertia, but your bold probability is based on a world where costly signaling works because the signaled product (the US college degree) and student access are both stable. Not this year. If you claim >60% on Caplan winning, you’re not forecasting—you’re hallucinating the future into sameness.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Reviewing the group, there's a near-unanimous tilt below 50%, especially among demographic and higher ed policy forecasters using direct enrollment and policy data signals. The only clear holdout is Economics (Signaling Theory), which I critiqued for underweighting the international enrollment collapse and overestimating institutional adaptation. Importantly, multiple domain experts highlighted that the velocity and directness of the international student pipeline shock is qualitatively different from baseline drift; base rate gradualism is explicitly superseded by actual news in 2025, and there is evidence that the under-26.6% scenario is not just possible but now more likely than not. That said, the consensus is tight (30–40% for 'Yes', with some outlier optimism), and base rate inertia could produce a near miss. Weighing all arguments—and the force of so many forecasters converging toward 'No'—I will revise very slightly downward to 35%, aligning with the strong aggregation around that number and my own sense that the downside risk is very real.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Upon reviewing the deliberation, I see strong consensus among demographers, policy experts, and access researchers: the magnitude and abruptness of the 2025 international student visa shock, in conjunction with continued domestic headcount pressures, makes a sub-26.6% outcome more likely than even my initial pessimistic baseline. Conversely, the optimistic takes (notably 'Economics (Signaling Theory)') rely on institutional inertia and base rates, but fail to grapple with the unique and universal character of this year’s international collapse—an event without direct historical parallel outside the COVID period, for which we have precedent that a 1–2 percentage point single-year enrollment rate decline is possible. Group dialogue reinforced that no level of admissions policy flexibility can fully offset a simultaneous domestic contraction and international implosion. This was further clarified in my own critique, and my reasoning aligns closely with others clustering around the 30–40% mark for a 'Yes' outcome. I see no new argument justifying a higher probability for Caplan’s win, and if anything, the boldest, best-supported call would even justify a lower estimate. However, I will stand at 30% to stay within justified, non-extreme territory.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I see that the majority of forecasters with serious data and policy expertise are clustered between 22% and 40%, with a few optimistic outliers arguing for resilience that doesn't stand up to the unprecedented, sharp, single-year collapse in new international undergrad enrollments. Critiques aimed at the more optimistic takes were persuasive, especially in highlighting the limits on denominator shrinkage and domestic backfill when the numerator faces a uniquely large exogenous shock. There is near-consensus among demographers and higher education policy analysts that historical inertia cannot override a shock of this scale in 2025, and there is agreement that every mitigating factor (institutional desperation, admissions policy flexibility) fails to fully counteract the abrupt implosion in international flow. Given that, my own analysis—already on the lower, bolder end—remains sound and in line with the evidenced consensus. No compelling new information in deliberation moves me toward a meaningful upward or downward adjustment. My final position is unchanged.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Engagement with other forecasters, particularly the critique of 'Economics (Demographic Transition)', further affirms the outsized numerical impact of the extraordinary international enrollment collapse—a near 17% drop in new intakes for 2025—against the already contracting U.S. 18-24 cohort. Optimistic arguments for denominator shrinkage or labor market cooling fail to stand up to the empirical magnitude of the international student shortfall, which cannot be quickly or meaningfully offset by institutional policy tweaks or recruitment desperation in a year of such acute exogenous shock. The historical inertia and resilience often cited are simply less persuasive against real, sharp declines already reported and embedded in institutional data. I see no new, credible upside scenario arising from deliberation; rather, the forum reinforced the downside risk and undermined case for Caplan's win. The argument for an even lower probability is tempting, but the proximity of pre-2025 data to the threshold and the possibility of limited measurement/lag effects (NCES smoothing, late reporting, deferrals) argues for not moving to an extreme. Therefore, I hold at 35%.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After group deliberation, I am even more persuaded that the historic, catastrophic 17% drop in new international students for Fall 2025 directly undercuts the four-year enrollment rate, and that base rate inertia—so frequently cited in defense of a higher probability Caplan wins—cannot realistically offset the velocity or magnitude of this shock. Critiques of denominator-padding optimism (from demographic transition theorists) are especially compelling: the shrinking 18-24 U.S. cohort hasn’t rescued the rate before, and there’s no plausible domestic or labor market offset for such a sharp international collapse. Every analysis—using IPEDS, NCES, status attainment, or student integration models—converges on the conclusion that this is not a gentle continuation of prior years, but a true exogenous disruption. The semester’s visa fiasco and international deterrents affect the exact population that props up the four-year rate at the margin. Even the most aggressive institutional backfilling can only do so much, and no forecaster credibly argued a compensating influx of domestic four-year enrollees. It is therefore justified to be even bolder and drop my probability further, pushing it toward group consensus. My best estimate is now that Caplan wins only about one in four times.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: My initial probability (22%) was quite bearish, emphasizing the structural and acute negative shocks to both international and domestic four-year enrollments in 2025. The group deliberation—most notably from demography, policy, and education analysts—reinforced my core arguments: the international student collapse is both historic and numerically immediate for the numerator, domestic demographic and attitudinal headwinds persist, and attempts at institutional mitigation can't plausibly compensate at this scale. Critics pressed the flaw in arguments for denominator shrinkage and signaled that base rate inertia is less relevant when the shock is exogenous, immediate, and already signaled in pipeline and policy data. No conversation participant credibly advanced new evidence that would justify raising my probability; if anything, the consensus sharpened around the likelihood that 2025 marks a discontinuity rather than a slow erosion. Further, no plausible scenario was floated in deliberations that would produce a substantial late recovery or statistical rescue for Caplan. Thus, while my initial call is strong, the collective expert exchange provides no reason to loosen it. My revised probability remains at 22%.

Economics (Signaling Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing group deliberation, it is clear the consensus has shifted strongly against Caplan: most other forecasters, spanning demographic, education, and social policy expertise, are considerably more bearish than my phase I probability. Their critiques highlight that the unprecedented 17% international undergraduate collapse is not just a marginal effect but a direct, near-instant hit to the key numerator, with little historical or statistical precedent for such a shock being fully backfilled by institutional adaptation in the same cycle, especially amid ongoing domestic demographic decline and skepticism about college value. Component analysis, IPEDS/NCES microdata, and historical patterns of abrupt policy and visa shocks all support notably sharper near-term drops than could be explained by inertia alone. Furthermore, the 'denominator buffer' and labor market cooling are convincingly shown to be insufficient in the face of such a numerically large and concentrated international loss—especially given the timing and geographic spread (India and China being paramount). The polled downside risk and rallying of domain experts toward a sub-40% probability that Caplan wins is persuasive: I likely overweighted institutional compensatory capacity and underweighted the scale and immediacy of this negative shock to the relevant 18-24 four-year cohort, particularly for a single-year result. Accordingly, I am compelled to sharply revise my probability downward, in line with (though not quite as extreme as) the prevailing evidence-weighted consensus.

Economics (Demographic Transition).reasoning_for_revised_probability: Group deliberation highlighted substantial and persuasive evidence that the international student collapse is not only acute in headline terms, but is directly relevant to the 18–24, four-year undergraduate cohort. Several forecasters, including those with access and demographic modeling expertise, rightly emphasized that the magnitude of the 2025 disruption—tied to a 17%+ fall in new international undergrads from core feeder nations—produces a numerator shock too large for easy domestic substitution or numerator/denominator buffering to cushion, especially given the ongoing demographic contraction and skepticism about college ROI domestically. My initial forecast weighed institutional adaptability and denominator shrinkage too heavily, underappreciating the limitations of those effects in the face of a single-year exogenous shock. The consensus among experts is that even the sector's heroic efforts are unlikely to backfill the loss within one enrollment cycle, and that data-dictated inertia is less operative amid discontinuous external events. Consequently, while it is still possible (via lag or reporting anomalies) that Caplan squeaks out a win, the odds are—on balance—now below even. I now judge that the risk of falling *below* the threshold is clearly dominant, and that a bold probability in the 30–40% range better reflects the synthesis of base rates and news. The revised forecast is thus a substantial move downward; Caplan is now the underdog.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).reasoning_for_revised_probability: Deliberation highlighted broad consensus—across demographic, policy, and education experts—that the 2025 international visa/entry crisis caused an enrollment shock of unprecedented scale for international undergraduates, with widespread agreement that this would have an immediate, material effect on the 18-24, four-year college enrollment rate. Critiques of the 'denominator shrinkage' offset called out its limitations: when the numerator (actual enrolled) suffers a one-year double-digit decline, especially from international full-payers who are disproportionately represented, historic base rate inertia is finally overwhelmed. Additionally, nearly all deliberators point out institutional desperation and admissions flex are not sufficient to plug a gap of this size given domestic student skepticism and demographic contraction. The rare scenario where Caplan wins now seems to ride on measurement quirks or an overestimate of the impact of compensatory behavior, not substantive enrollment resilience. My own status attainment sociological lens agrees that structural shocks of this abruptness usually overpower even robust countermeasures, and my phase one probability (62%) is best revised downward. While I don’t go as low as the most bearish (22-35%), I now see the chance Caplan wins as clearly below even odds, though not a complete rout.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing group deliberation, the most compelling critiques targeted any optimistic leanings based on institutional adaptability or denominator shrinkage. The cross-ensemble consensus, especially from demography and policy experts, powerfully reiterated that a 17% collapse in new international undergraduates is a direct, unmitigable numerical blow to the 4-year enrollment numerator, dwarfing any possible offset from domestic recruitment or demographic trends. No forecaster credibly argued for upside surprise; instead, the sharpest points were that similar historical shocks have always directly registered in NCES rates and that structural headwinds (visa disaster, ROI skepticism, cohort shrinkage) are unprecedentedly aligned downward. The wide agreement (30-40% range) also supports moving further below neutral odds. Given the totality of deliberation—statistical, structural, and institutional—I am more confident that Caplan is unlikely to win. I lower my probability by 5 points to reflect this reinforced downside risk.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Upon review of group deliberation, I now have even less optimism regarding the chances that Caplan will win. The critiques, particularly of the 'denominator will save us' optimism, are well-founded: the scale and recency of the international student collapse cannot be backfilled by domestic recruitment, especially as the domestic cohort is shrinking and skepticism of higher ed intensifies. Multiple methodological takes (demographic, social science, policy) converge on the conclusion that this is not a year of glacial drift but of historic shock, and that the combination of acute numerator loss and insufficient compensatory mechanisms makes a sub-26.6% enrollment rate more likely than not. Even the most optimistic defenses could only muster cases for a razor-thin survival, not a comfortable margin. Group consensus clusters probabilities between 30-40%, and the best-supported arguments point to real downside risk taking precedence. Therefore, I modestly lower my probability to reflect even greater weight on the international shock—bumping down from 38% to 34%.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, the prevailing view across relevant expert domains—demographics, education policy, social policy, and sociology—coalesces around the extraordinary severity of the 2025 international student supply shock and the inability of domestic or institutional countermeasures to fully compensate within the same academic year. Critiques of the more optimistic or inertia-based forecasts universally stress the magnitude, abruptness, and one-off nature of the current year’s disruption, as well as the limitations of denominator shrinkage given a collapsing numerator. No substantive argument suggests an overlooked mitigating factor that would substantially increase Caplan’s chances. If anything, the consensus has moved even further toward downside risk, with the modal forecast for a 'Yes' outcome (Caplan wins) now at or below my initial 35%, and several credible models pitched closer to 30%. Given this, it would be reasonable—indeed, prudent—to slightly lower my forecast to 30% to better reflect the intensified, argued consensus regarding the negative shocks' likely dominance. This fine-tunes my probability to more closely track the updated community view, while preserving the recognition of residual uncertainty.

question_details.title: Will Bryan Caplan win his bet that the college enrollment rate will be greater than  26.6% in 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-03-21 17:48:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/21922). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

**The wager for this question appeared [here](https://www.econlib.org/education-the-betting-continues/) and was made September 12th, 2018 at even odds. This wager was an update on a [previous post](https://www.econlib.org/archives/2011/10/stably_wasteful.html).**

Caplan writes:
>Samuel Knoche, a student at Fordham University, has taken me up on an old bet:

---

>I bet at even odds that 10 years from now, the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in traditional four-year colleges will be no more than 10% (not 10 percentage-points!) lower than it is today.

---

However, we’ve slightly modified the earlier terms.
> Since the most recent data is for 2015, we are betting that when the 2025 data comes out, Samuel [Knoche] wins if the fraction of 18-to-24-years-olds enrolled in four-year colleges has fallen more than 10%.  I win if it’s fallen less.  Since the current rate is 29.9%, he wins if the rate is 26.6% or less.  If the data series is discontinued, we call off the bet and I refund his money with 3% annual interest.

---

NOTE: This question is a resolution-reversed version of a previously opened Metaculus question: [Will the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in colleges in 2025 be ≥10% less than were enrolled in 2015?](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/1433/will-the-fraction-of-american-18-24-year-olds-enrolled-in-colleges-in-2025-be-10-less-than-were-enrolled-in-2015/)

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":21922,"question_id":21922}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
*This question belongs to the Bryan Caplan Collection, a series based on bets by economist Bryan Caplan. Find the rest of the series [here](https://www.metaculus.com/project/3053/) and Caplan's bet inventory covering most series questions [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1qShKedFJptpxfTHl9MBtHARAiurX-WK6ChrMgQRQz-0/edit).*

**Questions in this series resolve according to the outcome of Bryan Caplan's wager, where a resolution of 'Yes' reflects Caplan winning the bet. Questions resolve per public statements by Caplan.**

---

For this question, a resolution of YES reflects that Caplan won his bet that: the enrollment rate of 18- to 24-year-olds in a 4-year college or university in the [NCES 2025 data](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d23/tables/dt23_302.60.asp) is greater than  26.6%. 

If Caplan does not announce the outcome, this question resolves per [NCES data](https://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d16/tables/dt16_302.60.asp). If the data series is discontinued, the question will be annulled.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Will a Rate Cut Really Help? Only Some**
Wall Street expects a 0.25 percentage point interest rate cut at the upcoming Federal Reserve meeting, with a 90% probability according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. However, the article questions whether this traditional monetary policy will be effective in today's economy, which is marked by structural shifts. Recent data shows a 32,000-job decline in private payrolls, 1.17 million layoff announcements for 2025 (54% higher than the same period last year), cooling wage growth, falling consumer confidence, and rising delinquencies across credit cards, car loans, and student debt. The labor market is showing significant cracks. Historically, rate cuts stimulate the economy by lowering borrowing costs, encouraging investment, hiring, income growth, and consumer spending. However, in today’s K-shaped economy, where wealth concentration is increasing, rate cuts disproportionately benefit higher-income 'Upper-K' Americans who own assets, while lower-income 'Lower-K' Americans—whose purchasing power is eroding—see limited relief. The article argues that automation, AI, and robotics are driving a non-cyclical, structural shift that rate cuts cannot reverse. Even as rate cuts may slightly reduce financial pressure for lower-income households, they do not address job displacement caused by automation. The article concludes that rate cuts will likely boost asset prices and benefit investors more than workers, accelerating wealth concentration. It advocates for a strategic shift toward asset ownership—particularly in AI and automation-driven sectors—as the new path to financial security, framing this as 'American Dream 2.0.' The article promotes a private investor summit where experts will present a portfolio targeting tech and AI stocks, citing a prior portfolio’s 32% return—nearly triple the Dow and more than double the S&P 500—suggesting strong potential for future gains in this new economic paradigm.

**96% of US Colleges Say Visa Delays Are Killing Enrollment: Inside the State Department's Catastrophic Failure**
A catastrophic breakdown in the U.S. student visa processing system in 2025 has led to a 17% decline in new international student enrollment, the first drop after four years of post-COVID recovery, costing the U.S. economy $1.1 billion and nearly 23,000 jobs. According to a survey of 828 U.S. institutions, 96% reported that visa delays were a key factor in enrollment declines, and 91% reported visa denials affecting admitted students—many of whom had already paid deposits and received Form I-20s. The crisis intensified after a three-week visa processing pause from May 27 to June 18, which disrupted the peak application window for fall enrollment and created a cascading backlog. Wait times varied dramatically by location, with students in India, China, Nigeria, and Vietnam facing months-long delays, turning the process into a geographic lottery. Denial rates rose sharply, with Section 214(b), administrative processing, and documentation issues cited as common reasons—despite applicants being academically qualified. In contrast, competitor countries like Canada, the UK, Australia, and Germany have streamlined, reliable systems with faster processing, clear timelines, and post-study work rights, leading many students to choose alternatives. The State Department’s October 2025 improvements—92% of locations offering appointments within two months—came too late to prevent the damage. Chronic understaffing, budget constraints, pandemic-era backlogs, and poor coordination with academic calendars have undermined the system. Universities now operate emergency programs, face financial losses, and are forced to act as de facto immigration consultants. Experts call for immediate staffing surges, technology upgrades, standardized adjudication, and long-term structural reforms to restore trust. As Priya Sharma, who transferred to the University of Toronto, said: 'I wanted America first. But America told me no. Canada said yes in four weeks. I'm not looking back.' The crisis threatens America’s global leadership in higher education not due to academic quality, but due to systemic failure in visa processing.

**Federal funding cuts are only one problem facing America's colleges and universities**
American colleges and universities are facing significant financial and structural challenges beyond federal funding cuts under the Trump administration, which terminated grants valued between $6.9 billion and $8.2 billion since January 2025. Research universities, such as Johns Hopkins and MIT, rely heavily on federal research funding, which accounted for 40% of their total revenue in 2022-23. However, financial strain also stems from declining enrollment—8.4% fewer students in 2024 compared to the 2010 peak of 21 million—and reduced demand for certain academic programs. Many institutions, especially private nonprofits, operate like businesses, seeking revenue by admitting students with minimal academic requirements when seats are available, though fixed costs like faculty salaries and maintenance limit flexibility. Schools are increasingly competing through price discrimination, offering financial aid and scholarships—Harvard’s average net price in 2023-24 was $17,900—while relying on international students, who historically paid full tuition. However, foreign enrollment dropped 17% from fall 2024 to 2025, with Chinese student numbers falling from 317,299 in 2019 to 265,919 in 2024-25 due to stricter U.S. visa policies, geopolitical tensions, and increased competition from universities in Australia, Canada, and the UK. Additionally, the perceived value of a college degree is under scrutiny: only 22% of Americans believe a degree is worth the cost if financed through loans. Data from the University of Texas at Arlington shows stark disparities in return on investment—drama majors earned $14,933 one year post-graduation, with a negative $324,210 return over a decade, while civil engineering graduates earned $105,377 after 10 years, yielding a positive return of $1.15 million. The authors urge students and parents to treat college selection like a major financial decision, demanding transparency on graduate earnings and employment outcomes to drive institutional reform.

**Should College Come With a Money-Back Guarantee?**
The U.S. Department of Education has proposed new rules allowing students to sue universities for tuition reimbursement if the institution substantially misrepresents key aspects of education, such as graduate employability or program content. Unlike traditional fraud law (mens rea), which requires proof of intent, this new standard permits lawsuits even if the misrepresentation was unintentional—such as a clerical error. This could expose universities, including public institutions like the University of Colorado at Boulder, to liability, potentially requiring taxpayer funding for refunds. The proposal arises amid concerns over rising student debt—$1.2 trillion in 2015—and low graduation rates, with less than 20% of full-time students at public four-year colleges earning degrees within four years. The article draws a parallel between education and consumer goods: just as consumers can return defective products like cars, TVs, or spoiled milk for refunds, students might reasonably expect a similar recourse if their degree fails to deliver promised outcomes, such as job placement in their field. The central question posed is whether college should come with a money-back guarantee, reflecting a broader debate about accountability, value, and consumer protection in higher education.

**Will a Rate Cut Really Help? Only Some**
Wall Street expects a 0.25 percentage point interest rate cut at the upcoming Federal Reserve meeting, with a 90% probability according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. However, the article questions whether this traditional monetary policy will be effective in today's economy, which is marked by structural shifts. Recent data shows a 32,000-job decline in private payrolls, 1.17 million layoff announcements for 2025 (54% higher than the same period last year), cooling wage growth, falling consumer confidence, and rising delinquencies across credit cards, car loans, and student debt. The labor market is showing significant cracks. Historically, rate cuts stimulate the economy by lowering borrowing costs, encouraging investment, hiring, income growth, and consumer spending. However, in today’s K-shaped economy, where wealth concentration is increasing, rate cuts disproportionately benefit higher-income 'Upper-K' Americans who own assets, while lower-income 'Lower-K' Americans—whose purchasing power is eroding—see limited relief. The article argues that automation, AI, and robotics are driving a non-cyclical, structural shift that rate cuts cannot reverse. Even as rate cuts may slightly reduce financial pressure for lower-income households, they do not address job displacement caused by automation. The article concludes that rate cuts will likely boost asset prices and benefit investors more than workers, accelerating wealth concentration. It advocates for a strategic shift toward asset ownership—particularly in AI and automation-driven sectors—as the new path to financial security, framing this as 'American Dream 2.0.' The article promotes a private investor summit where experts will present a portfolio targeting tech and AI stocks, citing a prior portfolio’s 32% return—nearly triple the Dow and more than double the S&P 500—suggesting strong potential for future gains in this new economic paradigm.

**96% of US Colleges Say Visa Delays Are Killing Enrollment: Inside the State Department's Catastrophic Failure**
A catastrophic breakdown in the U.S. student visa processing system in 2025 has led to a 17% decline in new international student enrollment, the first drop after four years of post-COVID recovery, costing the U.S. economy $1.1 billion and nearly 23,000 jobs. According to a survey of 828 U.S. institutions, 96% reported that visa delays were a key factor in enrollment declines, and 91% reported visa denials affecting admitted students—many of whom had already paid deposits and received Form I-20s. The crisis intensified after a three-week visa processing pause from May 27 to June 18, which disrupted the peak application window for fall enrollment and created a cascading backlog. Wait times varied dramatically by location, with students in India, China, Nigeria, and Vietnam facing months-long delays, turning the process into a geographic lottery. Denial rates rose sharply, with Section 214(b), administrative processing, and documentation issues cited as common reasons—despite applicants being academically qualified. In contrast, competitor countries like Canada, the UK, Australia, and Germany have streamlined, reliable systems with faster processing, clear timelines, and post-study work rights, leading many students to choose alternatives. The State Department’s October 2025 improvements—92% of locations offering appointments within two months—came too late to prevent the damage. Chronic understaffing, budget constraints, pandemic-era backlogs, and poor coordination with academic calendars have undermined the system. Universities now operate emergency programs, face financial losses, and are forced to act as de facto immigration consultants. Experts call for immediate staffing surges, technology upgrades, standardized adjudication, and long-term structural reforms to restore trust. As Priya Sharma, who transferred to the University of Toronto, said: 'I wanted America first. But America told me no. Canada said yes in four weeks. I'm not looking back.' The crisis threatens America’s global leadership in higher education not due to academic quality, but due to systemic failure in visa processing.

**Colleges ease the dreaded admissions process as the supply of applicants declines**
The college admissions process is becoming less stressful and more accessible as institutions respond to a declining pool of 18-year-olds, with the number of high school graduates entering higher education projected to drop over the next 15 years. Federal data show that overall college acceptance rates have risen from about 5 in 10 applicants a decade ago to 6 in 10 today. To attract students, colleges are implementing one-click applications, waiving application fees (e.g., 130 New York state colleges waived $50–$90 fees in October), offering automatic admission to students who meet high school benchmarks (e.g., California State University accepts students with a C or higher in required courses), and extending unsolicited offers through the Common App—210 institutions made such offers in the 2025 cycle, nearly double the previous year. Pace University offers $1,000 annual financial aid to campus visitors, as research shows visitation doubles enrollment likelihood. Despite these efforts, perceptions persist: a Pew Research Center survey found 45% of Americans ages 18–29 believe college admissions is harder than for their parents’ generation, and over 75% find the process complex, with more than half calling it the most stressful experience in school. However, students who have already applied report lower stress levels than those preparing to apply. While direct admission and fee waivers increase applications—NY state saw a 41% rise in SUNY applications during a fee-waiver month—experts like James Murphy of Education Reform Now caution that such reforms primarily benefit colleges by boosting enrollment, not students, unless paired with financial aid and support. Additionally, colleges are extending deadlines, recruiting after May 1, and making standardized test scores optional (over 2,000 institutions now do so). A lawsuit has been filed against 32 schools practicing early decision, which binds students to enroll if accepted, arguing it limits financial aid negotiation. Experts like Kevin Krebs of HelloCollege emphasize that 'if you have the grades, you're going to get in' at many schools, asserting that students now hold more control over the process.

**Colleges say foreign students feel 'unwelcome' in the U.S. amid big drop in international enrollment, new survey finds**
A new survey by the Institute of International Education, based on responses from 828 U.S. colleges and universities, reveals a 17% drop in new international student enrollment for the fall 2025 semester, continuing a trend that saw a 7% decline in 2024. The decline is largely attributed to policies under the Trump administration, which targeted international education and immigration, including revoking visas of at least 1,800 foreign students (later reversed), pausing all new student visa interviews, proposing social media screening for applicants, and attempting to revoke Harvard University’s ability to host international students—a move blocked by a court. Nearly all institutions reporting decreased enrollment cited visa issues as a major obstacle, up from 64% during the first year of Joe Biden’s presidency. Additionally, two-thirds of schools said foreign students now feel 'unwelcome' in the U.S., a significant increase from 25% four years ago, with a similar proportion citing America’s 'social and political environment' as a deterrent. Although overall international enrollment declined by only 1%, this marks a reversal from post-pandemic growth. International students, who typically pay higher tuition and contribute $42.9 billion to the U.S. economy annually, supported over 355,000 American jobs in 2024–25; the current decline is projected to cost $1.1 billion and 23,000 jobs. Most international students are in graduate programs and concentrated in elite institutions on the East Coast and in California. Despite earlier hardline policies, President Trump recently adopted a softer tone, stating during a Fox News interview that reducing international enrollment too much would 'destroy our entire university and college system' and defending a plan to offer 600,000 visas to Chinese students, saying, 'It's not that I want them, but I view it as a business.'

**Trump Policies Blamed as U.S. Colleges See Sharp Drop in New International Students - Inquisitr News**
Universities across the United States are experiencing their steepest decline in new international student enrollment in years, with a 17% drop in new international students for the fall 2025 semester, following a 7% decline in the 2024–2025 academic year, according to the Open Doors report by the Institute of International Education. Campus officials attribute the downturn largely to policies under President Donald Trump’s administration, including a month-long pause in visa interviews over the summer, stricter vetting, and fewer available appointments, which left many admitted students unable to secure visas or arrive on time. More than half of surveyed institutions reported allowing students to defer enrollment, while a large majority said they continue to value international students for their academic and cultural contributions and financial importance—nearly 60% acknowledged their role in stabilizing institutional budgets. Despite the drop in new arrivals, overall foreign student enrollment is rising due to increased participation in Optional Practical Training (OPT), which grew by 21%, and longer stays in graduate and doctoral programs. University recruiters are now working to reassure prospective international students, but concerns remain over whether the decline in new enrollment—falling at a double-digit rate—is a temporary dip or the beginning of a long-term shift.

**July-August witness 50% drop in Indian students heading to US colleges: Trump's visa rules to blame?**
A 44.5% drop in Indian student arrivals to U.S. universities in August 2025—down from 74,825 to 41,540—along with a 46.4% decline in July, marks a sharp reversal from previous trends, according to data from the U.S. International Trade Administration. This decline, part of a broader 27% drop in visas issued to Indian students between March and May 2025 compared to 2024, is attributed to stricter visa policies under the Trump administration, including suspended interview slots, enhanced background checks (including social media scrutiny), rising processing fees, and tighter H-1B visa rules favoring higher-wage applicants. Indian students, who accounted for 27% of all international enrolments in U.S. universities in 2024, view the Optional Practical Training (OPT) and H-1B visa pathways as essential to their decision to study in the U.S., with a Forbes survey indicating that over half would not have enrolled if OPT were unavailable and 53% would not have applied if H-1B selection were based on wage levels. The decline threatens academic diversity and the financial stability of American universities, which rely heavily on international enrolments to offset stagnant domestic enrollment. Meanwhile, Canada, Australia, and the UK are gaining traction by offering clearer post-study work options and more predictable visa regimes. The article warns that unless current policies are reversed, the U.S. risks losing its status as the top destination for Indian students, with long-term consequences for higher education and the labor market. 'The dream of thousands of Indian students to study in the United States is losing its shine,' the article states, linking the downturn directly to 'tougher rules under the Trump administration.'

**Should College Come With a Money-Back Guarantee?**
The U.S. Department of Education has proposed new rules allowing students to sue universities for tuition reimbursement if the institution substantially misrepresents key aspects of education, such as graduate employability or program content. Unlike traditional fraud law (mens rea), which requires proof of intent, this new standard permits lawsuits even if the misrepresentation was unintentional—such as a clerical error. This could expose universities, including public institutions like the University of Colorado at Boulder, to liability, potentially requiring taxpayer funding for refunds. The proposal arises amid concerns over rising student debt—$1.2 trillion in 2015—and low graduation rates, with less than 20% of full-time students at public four-year colleges earning degrees within four years. The article draws a parallel between education and consumer goods: just as consumers can return defective products like cars, TVs, or spoiled milk for refunds, students might reasonably expect a similar recourse if their degree fails to deliver promised outcomes, such as job placement in their field. The central question posed is whether college should come with a money-back guarantee, reflecting a broader debate about accountability, value, and consumer protection in higher education.

summary:
Forecasters offer a relatively tight consensus that Bryan Caplan is now more likely than not to lose his bet that the 2025 NCES data will show the 18-24-year-old four-year college enrollment rate above 26.6%. Across the 12 analyses, the average probability assigned to Caplan winning is approximately 41%, with a median of around 36%, and individual assessments ranging from a low of 22% (Economics/Human Capital Theory: most pessimistic) to a high of 74% (Economics/Demographic Transition: most optimistic).

Key drivers identified by all experts include:
- A historically severe (>15%) drop in new international student enrollments for 2025, attributed to a visa processing crisis and hostile policy changes, particularly affecting incoming undergraduate cohorts from India and China. This exogenous shock is considered the most significant negative development, heavily weighing against Caplan's win.
- Ongoing demographic headwinds—fewer U.S. high school graduates reaching college age as the demographic 'cliff' arrives, further shrinking the pool of potential enrollees.
- Perceived declining value of four-year college, with only 22% of Americans thinking a degree is worth it if financed with loans, potentially leading more domestic students to opt out.
- Aggressive institutional countermeasures: Most analysts agree that U.S. four-year colleges have responded with extreme admissions flexibility—including waivers, auto-admit, direct admission, financial aid expansion, and extended deadlines—but generally doubt that these efforts can fully counterbalance both the international and demographic hits in a single year.

A minority of experts (notably in Demographic Transition, Signaling Theory, and Status Attainment approaches) are more optimistic. They emphasize historical base-rate inertia, institutional adaptability, and possible overstatement of the impact of the international drop on the relevant 18-24 undergrad figures. Their projections (62-74% Caplan win) stress that four-year rates have typically proven resilient even in the face of shocks (e.g., COVID years) and that the denominator (total 18-24 year-olds) is also contracting.

Most experts (from Education Studies, Sociology, Economics, US Social Policy, IPEDS/Data, and Demographic Analysis) judge the confluence of 2025's international shock with structural declines to be sufficiently powerful to put the enrollment rate at or just below the critical 26.6% line. They see Caplan's win probability as 22-40%. Only one forecast (Signaling Theory) places the win likelihood substantially above 50% (at 68%), with the others clustering between 22% and 40%.

Commonly described No-outcome (Caplan loses) scenarios involve the 18-24 four-year rate dipping just below 26.6%, driven by a confluence of international collapse and weak domestic intake, with recruitment efforts unable to fully compensate. Yes-outcome (Caplan wins) scenarios posit unprecedented institutional adaptability, last-minute policy recovery on visas, or denominator shrinkage outpacing the loss of enrollees, keeping the rate just above the threshold.

In sum, while there is no unanimity, the weight of informed expert opinion, grounded in base rates and reactive institutional behavior, now favors Caplan losing his bet, with the probability of a win judged notably below 50% but not vanishingly small—a near coin flip, but with odds now clearly against him due to the unique 2025 international student collapse.
